articles.title: Brain Health and Balanced Eating: New Research Findings
articles.description: A significant 2024 study published in Nature Mental Health found that a balanced dietary approach may be optimal for brain health, analyzing data from nearly 182,000 people.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard Medical School publication - Tier 1 medical source, peer-reviewed research from Nature Mental Health journal
articles.validation_status: Verified - Reputable source with recent publication date

articles.title: Plant-Based Diets and Healthy Aging: 30-Year Harvard Study
articles.description: Major 2025 Harvard study published in Nature Medicine examined over 105,000 adults over 30 years, finding that plant-based diets increase likelihood of healthy aging by up to 86%.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard Medical School - Leading medical institution, published in Nature Medicine, 30-year longitudinal study
articles.validation_status: Verified - New 2025 research from authoritative medical source with extensive study duration

articles.title: Butter vs Plant Oils: Harvard Study Shows 15% Mortality Risk Increase
articles.description: Harvard study published in JAMA Internal Medicine found that higher butter intake increases mortality risk by 15%, while plant oil consumption reduces death risk by 16%.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard research published in JAMA Internal Medicine - top-tier medical journal with rigorous peer review
articles.validation_status: Verified - Recent Harvard research in prestigious medical journal

articles.title: Sucralose (Splenda) May Increase Appetite: New 2025 Study
articles.description: 2025 research reveals that the artificial sweetener sucralose may increase appetite and cravings compared to table sugar or plain water, potentially affecting weight management.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard Health reporting on peer-reviewed research examining artificial sweetener effects on appetite regulation
articles.validation_status: Verified - Recent Harvard publication on current artificial sweetener research

articles.title: 4:3 Intermittent Fasting Shows Superior Weight Loss Results
articles.description: 2025 study found that 4:3 intermittent fasting (eating only 20% of usual calories on three fasting days per week) resulted in greater weight loss than traditional calorie restriction over one year.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard Health reporting on controlled study comparing intermittent fasting methods with traditional calorie restriction
articles.validation_status: Verified - Recent Harvard publication on latest intermittent fasting research

articles.title: Ultra-Processed Foods Linked to Shorter Lifespan in Older Adults
articles.description: 2025 studies continue to show that ultra-processed foods may shorten lifespan among older adults, with a 10% higher likelihood of death, particularly from heart disease and diabetes.
articles.credibility_notes: Harvard Health reporting on longitudinal studies examining ultra-processed food consumption and mortality outcomes
articles.validation_status: Verified - Recent Harvard publication on current ultra-processed food research

articles.title: Mediterranean Diet Named #1 for 7th Consecutive Year
articles.description: The Mediterranean diet has been named the #1 overall diet for 2025, with recent research showing it could reduce brain age by up to 50% through improved blood sugar control.
articles.credibility_notes: WebMD - Established health information platform, reporting on U.S. News & World Report rankings
articles.validation_status: Verified - Recent publication citing established diet ranking methodology

articles.title: How Diet in Your 40s Affects Health in Your 70s
articles.description: Research involving over 106,000 people found that eating habits in your 40s significantly influence physical health, cognitive function, and mental well-being in later years.

infographics.credibility_notes: WHO is the leading global health authority, guidelines based on extensive peer-reviewed research and expert consensus
